metadata.title: W3Schools.com
metadata.Keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website
metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: JSON PHP
A common use of JSON is to read data from a web server, and display the data in a web page.
content.html: A common use of JSON is to read data from a web server, and display the data in a web page.

content.text: This chapter will teach you how to exchange JSON data between the client and a PHP server.
content.html: This chapter will teach you how to exchange JSON data between the client and a PHP server.

content.text: The PHP File
PHP has some built-in functions to handle JSON.
content.html: PHP has some built-in functions to handle JSON.

content.text: Objects in PHP can be converted into JSON by using the PHP function json_encode() :
content.html: Objects in PHP can be converted into JSON by using the PHP function json_encode():

content.code_html:
<?php
$myObj->name = "John";
$myObj->age = 30;
$myObj->city = "New York";

$myJSON = json_encode($myObj);

echo $myJSON;
?>

content.text: The Client JavaScript
Here is a JavaScript on the client, using an AJAX call to request the PHP file from the example above:
content.html: Here is a JavaScript on the client, using an AJAX call to request the PHP file from the example above:

content.code_html:
const xmlhttp = new XMLHttpRequest();
xmlhttp.onload = function() {
  const myObj = JSON.parse(this.responseText);
  document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = myObj.name;
}
xmlhttp.open("GET", "demo_file.php");
xmlhttp.send();

content.text: PHP Array
Arrays in PHP will also be converted into JSON when using the PHP function json_encode() :
content.html: Arrays in PHP will also be converted into JSON when using the PHP function json_encode():

content.code_html:
<?php
$myArr = array("John", "Mary", "Peter", "Sally");

$myJSON = json_encode($myArr);

echo $myJSON;
?>

content.text: The Client JavaScript
Here is a JavaScript on the client, using an AJAX call to request the PHP file from the array example above:
content.html: Here is a JavaScript on the client, using an AJAX call to request the PHP file from the array example above:

content.code_html:
var xmlhttp = new XMLHttpRequest();
xmlhttp.onload = function() {
  const myObj = JSON.parse(this.responseText);
  document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = myObj[2];
}
xmlhttp.open("GET", "demo_file_array.php", true);
xmlhttp.send();

content.text: PHP Database
PHP is a server side programming language, and can be used to access a database.
content.html: PHP is a server side programming language, and can be used to access a database.

content.text: Imagine you have a database on your server, and you want to send a request to it from the client where you ask for the 10 first rows in a table called "customers".
content.html: Imagine you have a database on your server, and you want to send a request to it from the client where you ask for the 10 first rows in a table called "customers".

content.text: On the client, make a JSON object that describes the numbers of rows you want to return.
content.html: On the client, make a JSON object that describes the numbers of rows you want to return.

content.text: Before you send the request to the server, convert the JSON object into a string and send it as a parameter to the url of the PHP page:
content.html: Before you send the request to the server, convert the JSON object into a string and send it as a parameter to the url of the PHP page:

content.code_html:
const limit = {"limit":10};
const dbParam = JSON.stringify(limit);
xmlhttp = new XMLHttpRequest();
xmlhttp.onload = function() {
  document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = this.responseText;
}
xmlhttp.open("GET","json_demo_db.php?x=" + dbParam);
xmlhttp.send();

content.text: Example explained:
Take a look at the PHP file:
content.html: Take a look at the PHP file:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
<?phpheader("Content-Type: application/json; charset=UTF-8");$obj = 
  json_decode($_GET["x"], false);
  $conn = new mysqli("myServer", "myUser", "myPassword", "Northwind");
  $stmt = $conn->prepare("SELECT name FROM customers LIMIT ?");$stmt->bind_param("s", $obj->limit);$stmt->execute();$result = $stmt->get_result();
  $outp = $result->fetch_all(MYSQLI_ASSOC);echo json_encode($outp);?>

content.code:
<?phpheader("Content-Type: application/json; charset=UTF-8");$obj = 
json_decode($_GET["x"], false);
$conn = new mysqli("myServer", "myUser", "myPassword", "Northwind");
$stmt = $conn->prepare("SELECT name FROM customers LIMIT ?");$stmt->bind_param("s", $obj->limit);$stmt->execute();$result = $stmt->get_result();
$outp = $result->fetch_all(MYSQLI_ASSOC);echo json_encode($outp);?>

syntax_highlighting.text:
<?phpheader("Content-Type: application/json; charset=UTF-8");$obj = 
  json_decode($_GET["x"], false);
 $conn = new mysqli("myServer", "myUser", "myPassword", "Northwind");
  $stmt = $conn->prepare("SELECT name FROM customers LIMIT ?");$stmt->bind_param("s", $obj->limit);$stmt->execute();$result = $stmt->get_result();
  $outp = $result->fetch_all(MYSQLI_ASSOC);echo json_encode($outp);?>

content.code_html:
<?php
header("Content-Type: application/json; charset=UTF-8");
$obj = json_decode($_GET["x"], false);

$conn = new mysqli("myServer", "myUser", "myPassword", "Northwind");
$stmt = $conn->prepare("SELECT name FROM customers LIMIT ?");
$stmt->bind_param("s", $obj->limit);
$stmt->execute();
$result = $stmt->get_result();
$outp = $result->fetch_all(MYSQLI_ASSOC);

echo json_encode($outp);
?>

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
<?phpheader("Content-Type: application/json; charset=UTF-8");$obj = 
  json_decode($_GET["x"], false);
  $conn = new mysqli("myServer", "myUser", "myPassword", "Northwind");
  $stmt = $conn->prepare("SELECT name FROM customers LIMIT ?");$stmt->bind_param("s", $obj->limit);$stmt->execute();$result = $stmt->get_result();
  $outp = $result->fetch_all(MYSQLI_ASSOC);echo json_encode($outp);?>

content.text: PHP File explained:
Use the Data

content.code_html:
xmlhttp.onload = function() {
  const myObj = JSON.parse(this.responseText);
  let text = "";
  for (let x in myObj) {
    text += myObj[x].name + "<br>";
  }
  document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = text;
}

content.text: PHP Method = POST
When sending data to the server, it is often best to use the HTTP POST method.
content.html: When sending data to the server, it is often best to use the HTTP POST method.

content.text: To send AJAX requests using the POST method, specify the method, and the correct header.
content.html: To send AJAX requests using the POST method, specify the method, and the correct header.

content.text: The data sent to the server must now be an argument to the send() method:
content.html: The data sent to the server must now be an argument to the send() method:

content.code_html:
const dbParam = JSON.stringify({"limit":10});
const xmlhttp = new XMLHttpRequest();
xmlhttp.onload = function() {
  const myObj = JSON.parse(this.responseText);
  let text ="";
  for (let x in myObj) {
    text += myObj[x].name + "<br>";
  }
  document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = text;
}
xmlhttp.open("POST", "json_demo_db_post.php");
 xmlhttp.setRequestHeader("Content-type", "application/x-www-form-urlencoded");
xmlhttp.send("x=" + dbParam);

content.text: The only difference in the PHP file is the method for getting the transferred data.
content.html: The only difference in the PHP file is the method for getting the transferred data.

syntaxHighlighting.text:
<?phpheader("Content-Type: application/json; charset=UTF-8");
  $obj = 
  json_decode($_POST["x"], false);
  
  $conn = new mysqli("myServer", "myUser", "myPassword", "Northwind");
  $stmt = $conn->prepare("SELECT name FROM customers LIMIT ?");$stmt->bind_param("s", 
  $obj->limit);$stmt->execute();$result = $stmt->get_result();
  $outp = $result->fetch_all(MYSQLI_ASSOC);echo json_encode($outp);?>
